reviewText: We've seen it all...the gory party-scene (Hellraiser) the traps (Saw and Cube)... yawn. And like with the first one: I feel not beeing taken seriously. How can ONE person build all that stuff and install it (in the first one even in a few hours? a WHOLE house?) without a dozen helping hands? No, I don't like it... the makers of this two turds seem to think horror-buffs are stupid. On the pro-side are the great atmosphere and the decent acting... but that doesn't safe this time-waster from beeing below mediocre. No cigar...
summary: As stupid as the first one...

reviewText: THE COLLECTION picks up where THE COLLECTOR left off, w/ the black-masked villain up to no good once more. This time, he takes out an entire rave party in quick, gruesomely-efficient fashion. Enter Elena (Emma Fitzpatrick), the sole survivor of his latest slaughter. She's apprehended by TC and taken back to his lair. Meanwhile, Arkin (Josh Stewart) the latest captive from the first film, returns as an escapee from TC's clutches. Now, Elena's father has called in a hit-team to go after TC, and they want Arkin to lead them to his hideout. Said hideout is quite a place! It's an ancient, abandoned hotel turned into a macabre, ghoulish house of horrors. It's, obviously, filled w/ booby-traps and other gadgets to entertain / mutilate any intruders. Can Arkin and company locate and save Elena in time? What new nightmares await them in TC's insidious "funhouse"? THE COLLECTION is a fantastic sequel that expands the story, adding twists and surprises, while taking us inside TC's utterly black world. Highly recommended for the not-so-easily-sickened...

reviewText: Check out my horror blog at: brandoncsites.blogspot.comThe Collection (2012) **1/2D: Marcus DunstanC: Josh Stewart, Emma Fitzpatrick, Courtney Lauren Cumming, Christopher McDonald, Lee Tergesen, Randall Archer, Shannon Kane, Andre Royo, Tim Griffin, William Peltz, Erin Way, Eaddy Mays, Brandon Molale, Justin Mortelliti, Navi RawatP: The lone survivor of the original film (The Collector) is abducted from his hospital bed and coerced into helping out a group of mercenaries raid "The Collector's" lair, an abandoned warehouse that has been booby trapped, all in an effort to save a young woman who has kidnapped by The Collector.Let me get this out of the way, we're not watching Shakespeare here! Now what we are watching is a film that is fun, fast paced and entertaining.A horror film needs to be a like a roller-coaster ride in many ways. You laugh. You scream. You sit there in your sit dreading the anticipation of horror. And when it is all said and done, you come away from it all having a good time. In that sense, The Collection is a success, in that it meets all those requirements.Now, I will say this, The Collection is one of those films whose script would not stand up to close scrutiny. In some ways, it even feels like a ripoff of Aliens and just about any film in the Saw franchise. The Collection isn't a film that is going to enlighten you or provide you any great depth or meaning. Even the acting is completely over the top.Different people are going to say a lot of different things about this film. Some of it good, a lot of it bad, but one thing The Collection isn't, it isn't boring. [R] 82 mins.
summary: Entertaining if you're willing to go along with it.

reviewText: This was in my opinion one of the top 3 Horror films of 2012.My only gripe is that it was much too short at a running time of 82 minutes.Although they did make every moment count and didn't waste any time on anything boring.I watched it twice, back to back that's how much I enjoyed it.All the actors were great and the characters well thought out.The gore was off the chain and the effects were pretty amazing.The visuals and cinematography were amazing as well.I saw some glimpses of or maybe homages to The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and Maniac in certain scenes,you will know which I am speaking of when you view the film.It had non stop action with many grit your teeth moments and a couple of cheer out loud moments.It was highly superior to it's predecessor ,one because the budget was much much larger and I pretty much loved that one as well,The concept was so intriguing and you don't find that many intriguing horror concepts these days.Most new horror flicks incorporate Found Footage I say enough already with that.The ending of This film was completely gratifying to me and I believe will be to you as well.Buy The Collection and The Collector for 'your' Collection.
summary: I will be adding this to "my" Collection
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is worth 5 stars just for the fact that there was never a dull moment throughout the movie. It kept me entertained & on the edge of my seat the whole time. Not easy for the otherwise washed out movies that come out in this genre. There is no time wasted with developing characters or backgrounds. We dive right in with an amazing nightclub massacre scene. One of the best since that scene from Blade.Josh Stewart makes for a great unsuspecting protagonist - the guy who you wouldn't peg as your first choice to be the hero but comes out on top in the end. I loved the background / musical score. Especially noteworthy is the scene towards the end where you feel you are going to lose our protagonist Arkin (Josh Stewart)to burning flames. Just as you think all is lost, Emma Fitzpatrick's character smashes the showcases filled with water and saves him. The track that plays during this scene (Out of the fire by Charlie Clouser) is especially uplifting and fits the scene so well. I loved it! Great, great score by Clouser.The end is left open for another movie obviously and you know what I can't wait to see it! Catch this for sure if you are a fan of the torture porn / slasher genre.
summary: Refreshing for the genre! .. SPOILERS INSIDE

reviewText: For reasons I've never quite considered, I do like a good horror picture.  Oh, I don't think that makes me a sick or psychotic person at all.  I think it's that horror - a truly good (not great) horror film - taps into some of our deepest fears.  About the dark.  About abduction.  About knives or bullets or other blunt instruments.  About isolation.  About being caged.  About the sight of blood.  About entrapment.  About bugs.  About killers.  About death, even.  Life is so fragile, after all, and we never truly know when it's going to be taken away from us, and some folks who make good horror (again, not great) learned a long time ago that "if you build it, people will come."(NOTE: The following review will contain minor spoilers necessary solely for the discussion of plot and characters.  If you're the kind of reader who prefers a review entirely spoiler-free, then I'd encourage you to skip down to the last two paragraphs for my final assessment.  If, however, you're accepting of a few modest hints at `things to come,' then read on ...)Elena (played by the comely Emma Fitzpatrick) didn't realize that she was in for the night of her life by attending what she thought was going to be a killer underground `rave' warehouse party.  Well, `killer' was right as it turns out the venue was little more than an elaborate booby trap meant to ensnare hundreds of victims for `The Collector,' the latest masked psychopath to put teens on the run.  By a strange twist of fate, Elena frees Arkin - the Collector's last intended victim - and just when the man thinks he's finally free, he finds himself abducted once more: this time by a team of crack mercenaries hired by Elena's millionaire father.  Despite the odds being stacked against them, they're intent on finding the young girl before any harm comes of her, but they'll need Arkin to led them back into the territory of his deepest, darkest fears if they're to have a chance.God only knows what's waiting for them ...THE COLLECTION is a sequel to 2009's modest hit THE COLLECTOR, which was the first to feature the said psychopath - a masked man whose apparently fetish is to collect human specimens for display in his own grotesque menagerie.  And, for all its faults, I thought much of THE COLLECTION to actually be well-made if not a bit predictable, delivering exactly the same kind of nerve-wracking suspense audiences long enamored with the SAW franchise have come to expect.  How is that possible?  Well, it's probably because the writers of SAW IV, V, VI, and VII were none other than Patrick Melton and Dunstan - the same team at work here.So - much like has already been done in the SAW yarns - audiences can expect more than the lion's share of elaborate traps and get-ups that promise to produce more blood per ounce than any other franchise worth its weight in human bones.  Yes, it's gratuitous, but it's just what the doctor ordered when it comes to contemporary horror.  For that matter, as much as we protest things used to be different, there really isn't that much difference stylistically in this than say most schlock produced in the 80's; if anything, the writers have grown a bit more involved in fleshing out the craziness (pun intended), and the film works entirely on that level.To her credit, Fitzpatrick rises to the challenge, becoming the newest scream queen to enter that unfortunate sorority of actresses.  She's to be commended for showing up, taking her punches, and rising to the challenge to save the hero when the stakes are down.  Josh Stewart returns as Arkin (from the first film), and he as well embodies the character with enough cynicism to make him real along with enough realism to make audiences root for him.  The rest of the cast?  Meh, it feels a bit obligatory, almost as much so as having the main protagonist wear a leather fetish mask.  Didn't Jason and Leatherface corner the market on those scares?  Is there really room for one more?If anything, THE COLLECTION's downside is that it expects its audience to suspend disbelief perhaps a bit farther than most films of this variety.  I mean just how much disposal income can one psychopath have?  He's outfitted an old hotel with hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of equipment and steel and traps; where does he get all of his money?  I honestly expected that there would be some grand reveal in the final reel, and I expected he'd pull off his mask to show me none other than Donald Trump waiting underneath.  But, alas, it wasn't meant to be.THE COLLECTION is produced by LD Entertainment and Fortress Features.  DVD distribution is being handled through Lionsgate.  As for the technical specifications, the film looks and sounds about as good as anything else in the horror genre these days; there are a few directorial flourishes compliments of Dunstan (who pulls double duty here as writer and director) that could've used some tightening, but film is a form of art.  Lastly, there are a wealth of special features - five short flicks exploring the film and the process; a handful of alternate scenes; the theatrical trailer; as well as Dunstan and Melton's audio commentary - that should keep interested parties glued to their seats if not already impaled on them!RECOMMENDED.  It may not be perfect.  It may not be the most original.  But THE COLLECTION is lean and mean enough at just over 80 minutes that it should keep the interest of horror fans, at least, and that's no easy feat.  Enjoy it for what it's worth - don't look for it to make perfect sense - and you're liable to have as much fun with it as I did.In the interests of fairness, I'm pleased to disclose that the fine folks at Lionsgate provided me with an advance DVD copy of THE COLLECTION by request for the expressed purposes of completing this review.
summary: Suspend Your Disbelief And Be Scared Silly Of THE COLLECTION

reviewText: I suppose torture/slasher flicks have their place in modern cinema, but this is about as vile an outing as I've ever seen. Now when I hear the term pornographic violence, I know what they're talking about.Here's the scoop. The Collector is back at it big time. He's holding the city hostage with fear. One night Elena (Emma Fitzpatrick) goes to a club. The Collector has set up an elaborate, Rube Goldberg-ish contraption and begins killing the club goers wholesale. Emma ends up locked in one of his trunks. Her rich father has his bodyguard recruit some buds to rescue her. But, to do so, he must hire another convicted killer to show them The Collector's lair. Said killer is the only one to ever have escaped The Collector with his life. He leads them into the lion's den.This is monstrous. It's filled with a lot of quick-cut shock visuals. Bugs, blood, dismembered corpses and all other kind of vile garbage. Of course The Collector's lair is filled with booby-traps and people get killed, maimed or dismembered in any number of clever ways. The rescue team have a sharp, tough, hip look (and of course one of them is female) but they're anything but tough and sharp. They get picked off with little problem. The colors are over saturated and tend toward a sickly pallor. It were as though the produces/director tried to think of every disturbing image possible and through it out there. And, as has been done before, the killer leading the rescue team into darkness is the one guy you end up rooting for. There are some clever turns in the plot and you want Emma outta there so there is some investment into what is happening. But, overall, this is some pretty sick stuff. I can only wonder who will try to top this and what could it possibly encompass?I like a good fright film as much as the next guy but this is just an exercise in shock.

reviewText: I love movies like this for some reason. It's very suspenseful and sick and twisted. It's nothing really like Saw or Hostel but it most definitely has a good bit of gore. This movie is not necessarily unique but it very interesting.Its basically your worst nightmare in a nut shell. Very Good Ending ! The movie keeps you at the edge of your seat the entire time . Some things you may find in the movie (bugs,club, barbed wire, torture, mangled bodies,mask,makeup,teeth,intestines,kidnapped,box, experiment,abandoned hospital,gun,cops,thief)I like the movie ,it kept me interested, gore was done well... enough said. If you like creepy, sick, twisted films this is right up your alley. If your into more paranormal than this isn't going to be your movie. Acting in this film is great as well. I actually really liked the two main characters in this film because they were actually smart . All in all this movie is good just watch it !

reviewText: More like a collection of all the slasher/ mutilation ingredients that have been tried and tested from the movie industry's kitchen. However careful marketing goes into knowing what makes us squirm or holler in a horror movie these day  . So it did deliver. There are so many crappy 2 and 1 star horror flics out there,  it maybe helps raise the rating on ones like this one. It will  hold your attention for the next nasty bit provided you have something to distract you from giving it your undivided attention at the time. Or maybe I'm just a sucker for mutilation and pit in the pendulum theatrics. Has terrible acting, naturally.
summary: yet another from movie industry's conveyor belt but not a 2star

reviewText: The Collection is the sequel to the sometimes clever film, The Collector, about a killer who kidnaps people to turn them into parts of his museum of madness.Note: The first 20 minutes of the film alone earns this film its high gore rating.This film takes place shortly after the first one, where the protagonist is forced to venture back into the killer's lair shortly after he escapes.A pack of mercenaries are hired to retrieve one of the Collector's latest victim's by her rich daddy; they dragoon the first movie's protagonist into helping them.Mayhem ensues, since the killer's house/museum is loaded with booby traps and alarms; not to mention a homicidal maniac.In my opinion, this film is better than most of these chop-crazy film murder-fests due to the story and the actors involved.I also liked the ending.The Collector is worth a look.

reviewText: Yikes!  Where do I begin....I had to turn my head a few times (but I ended up peeking, look - but don't look) oh my my my. Let's see, in a nutshell I'll say:  Gore-check (and lots of it); Blood-you bet; Slashing-Yep; Intelligence-oh my, yes; screaming at the screen to warn the actors-SEVERAL TIMES; edge of my seat-oh yes ma'am and then some; Killer believable-oh, my, my this dude was a sick son of a gun...sicko, sicko sicko; Killer good at his job-yepper, certainly doesn't leave anything half finished.  I hope you get the picture about this picture, as far as pictures go, and they do come and go feverishly these days...it's nice to see someone take pride in a job well done, like our murderer.  Actors:  believable and then some.  Story tied up neatly with a bow for you at the end (I liked not feeling like I was set up for a sequel).  This movie is a roller coaster from the first 5 minutes to the last 30 seconds, it winds you up and winds you up tight.  Don't miss this one...I've only written a few reviews when I want to express the awesomeness of a film for you.....don't miss this one if you love your blood, guts, gore, slashers and contraptions, you get it all and then some in The Collection.
summary: YOU GET IT ALL!  WHAT A THRILL RIDE

reviewText: the original Collector was a rather good movie....although nothing new, it was filmed very well and the traps were AWESOME. the original did lack a backstory on the Collector himself....very vague and absent of any reason for killing. just a madman.fine.this movie is the same, no real story or reason for any of it. they had a chance to really hash out a great plot and keep this franchise alive but chose to do more of the same. no reason for any of it. after a hour it is quite possibly the most vacant movie ever made. empty of anything. stupid.i do have to give it up to the first twenty minutes...the club scene was great, but immediately after that downhill fast. and seriously....how did this guy have money and knowledge to do all the sophisticated traps?? who knows?!? and at this point...who cares?!!!first twenty = awesome.  the rest : LAME.COULD HAVE BEEN AWESOME.

reviewText: Despite watching the wrong movie of this series first due to some poor searching on my part on Netflix and not caring I was watching a sequel when I realized I was several minutes into the film I really enjoyed this movie. Josh Steward always does an excellent job in films in my opinion and this movie lends itself wells to his scowly demeanor. I thought Emma Fitzpatrick was also excellent in this film as well, playing the tough survivor chick in horror movies is not always easy, as proven time and time again in some bad casting choices in other movies over the years and she does it well. Overall I was on my edge of the seat the entire time, the traps were really horrifying and I definitely found myself looking away a few times. I recommend this movie for gory horror film lovers.
summary: I Watched the Wrong One First

reviewText: From its over-the-top and gruesome opening to its fiery finale, THE COLLECTION is a non-stop roller coaster ride!  This tense sequel to THE COLLECTOR has booby traps to rival the SAW franchise.  The movie keeps things moving, not really focusing on characters but on the battle to avoid a horrific demise.Josh Stewart returns as the embattled hero, joined by Emma Fitzpatrick, Lee Tergesen and Christopher McDonald in supporting roles.THE COLLECTION is an effective thriller and horror fans should check it out.

reviewText: This is a horror sequel where you don't have to see the first to follow along, but it does bring back the main  hero and villain from the previous movie. The cult following of the original made this film possible, so give it a look. A thief breaks in a house and ends up trying to save the family being tortured by another unwanted vistor that beat him to scene. But wait, this killer has set up believable traps all over the house. The sequel expands the scope to an old hotel and has 10 times the body count. The first is dark and isolated, much like Alien. And like Aliens, the sequel is more in your face and action oriented. There are still a few really good scares and plenty of gore, with a villain that is truly chilling in appearance and the way he kills. Think Jigsaw and his traps, but he also does some of his killings himself with his arsenal of knives. My theater was actually half full (I thought I'd be alone) and people clapped when it was over.

reviewText: It was okay but it was predictable. Besides, with as many missing people and the couple captives he had, what made the one woman so worth risking everyone's life and limb for? That was hard to buy into.  Also, I am so tired of cops in movies going to a potential crime scene without first calling for back up.  Ya know, like just incase a crazy psycho dude kills off the team and maybe, just maybe the back up can help??? Very bloody also.  Maybe too bloody.  And no explanation as to really why he collects what he does except for the very end.  I will say I did like the ending for a change though. Now that is how to deal with a psycho!  It's a decent rental with a glass of wine....or two.

reviewText: Splatter I suppose is as legitimate a genre of film as any other. I can remember 40 some odd years ago when my father took me to see the Sam Peckinpah classic "The Wild Bunch" I had never seen so much blood it seemed to burst off the screen.They probably used more squibs (small explosive packets of stage blood) then any film of it's time. When I read that director Marcus Dunstun (Saw Franchise) saw this film as a tribute to splatter pictures I thought to myself that he had paid proper homage to the movies he loves.We streamed "The Collection" on a lark and I have to say were surprisingly entertained by it. Rich production value and great lighting must have eaten much of the budget, well that and untold gallons of stage blood and gore - but nonetheless the atmosphere is bleak, un nerving and immediate.There's an unexpected and at times comical creativity to how the cast is killed off and welcome shots albeit cliche' abound such as double doors swinging open to show our hero or nemeses in silhouette, a weapon of huge, toy like proportion in each hand. It's images like this that had me remembering playing Doom on a 486 computer.The cast is surprisingly solid, a good notch up from the wooden  "community theater" levels of acting we usually see associated with these kinds of films. It's also refreshing to see a complete absence of thirty year olds playing victimized high school students.The Collection isn't brain food, you're not going to find yourself discussing sub plots and deeper meanings here. It annoys me no end when arm chair pundits review these kinds of movies as if they were Shakespeare. They aren't and they "know" they aren't.What "The Collector" is albeit forgettable - is a wicked and very bloody good time.

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: Elena (Emma Fitzpatrick ) is the daughter of a wealthy man. When she is taken captive by the Collector (Randall Archer) at a rave, her father (Christopher McDonald) hires a SWAT team to go get her. They employ the services of the reluctant Arkin (Josh Stewart)the only man who has ever escaped from him.The Collector's warehouse is filled with booby traps. Plenty of blood and body parts. Light on "one on one" torture, relatively speaking. This movie simply goes through the motions. Let's put more killings in the feature and neglect a decent plot and characters. This is bordering on gore for sake of gore. If you are a big fan of "The Collector" and have been able to watch all "The Saw" movies without getting bored, you know you will watch this one too.For me, one gadget killing after another is getting tiresome. Can we have a pause for drama and plot?Parental Guide: F-bombs, brief nudity, no sex.

reviewText: The Collection starts off right where 2009's The Collector leaves off. The former was such a popular direct-to-video rental, that it's sequel actually wound up on the big screen, and how it avoided an NC-17 rating is beyond me. I've seen a ton of Horror movies, it's one of my favorite genres, so I can say, without hesitation that The Collection is one of the creepiest, goriest, and most clever Horror films I have ever seen. This crazed man in a mask is looking to collect certain types of people and if they pass his test, they can join his collection. If they fail, they become experiments in human suffering. In the first film, we see career criminal, Arkin O'Brien, fighting for his life. In the sequel, we see Arkin escape and lead a band of mercenaries back to the Collectors hideout, in order to rescue a captured rich girl. Of course once they get there, they find a maze of terror that rivals any film you've ever seen. I thought some of the machines in the Saw films were clever, but until you see this film, you haven't seen anything yet! How people come up with these things is beyond rational thought. Of all the ways to torture people, to come up with machines and techniques that exceed everything we've seen before is just sick...sick and very cool. The cast is the same as in every Horror movies, a bunch of dumb, no named actors, following a couple of smart people in order to stay alive as long as they can. What's special here is the story, the affects, and the level of depravity. The Collection is one of the most violent and gruesome Horror films to come along in years. It's the first step in the evolution of Horror that fans have been waiting for for years.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "You're not strong enough, you're never gonna make it." Arkin (Stewart) escapes from The Collector's house and is going to the hospital trying to recover, before he can get there he is once again abducted and is forced to help a wealthy man rescue his daughter from yet another booby trapped house. Can Arkin survive another round of hell? I will admit that I did like the Saw series, but because of the actual story line and not because of the huge amounts of gore, although I will say that did add to the story. The Collector was trying so hard to be Saw but never quite got there. I'm not sure why they made a sequel but I sat down to watch. While this one had much more gore and many more people being cut up it was essentially the same movie as the first one. I realize people that watch these aren't in it for the plot, but there needs to be some difference to warrant a sequel I think. On the other hand this movie is pretty much just made for people who love gore so I could be wrong. Overall, a little over an hour of blood and dismembering, so if you are into that then this is for you. I give it a C-.
summary: A little more then an hour of gore, blood and dismembering so if that's what you are looking for don't miss this. I say C-

reviewText: The collector was pretty good terror flick,that gained a cult following,due to positive word of mouth,now we get the sequel,which I thought tried to entertain you more than scare you,a rich girl goes out with her friends and get caught by the collector,her rich father hires mercenaries to rescue her,the mercenaries use a escapee from the first movie to help locate the girl,the plot with the use of a solid back story for this type of movie was excellent, the escapee used his instincts as a thief to back trace where he was captured,the viewer was shown that and that was well done,the traps and the high gore level was used to elevate to story and draw shock!It was more of an action terror movie to me,and that was good enough for this type of film,a good Saturday night double feature type of flick,both movies were pretty entertaining to me.
